item.title: By: Rob Wilkerson
item.dc:creator: Rob Wilkerson
item.content:encoded:
@Steve

I’d argue that it’s a delete-existing-right-click op, but that may just be splitting hairs. ðŸ™‚

You can export from your own working copy or _to_ it? I know the latter, of course, and the problem is that you may be exporting from a repository to a working directory that has updated code. That was my concern. Nonetheless, it’s a 6-of-one-half-dozen-of-the-other thing. To each his own.

item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description:
@Rob - I use TortoiseSVN, so for me it is a right-click, context menu op.
@Rob,@Ryan - you can direct svn export to pull from the repo or your current working copy. I've only ever used it against my current working copy (so I learned something here!)
item.content:encoded:
@Rob – I use TortoiseSVN, so for me it is a right-click, context menu op.

@Rob,@Ryan – you can direct svn export to pull from the repo or your current working copy. I’ve only ever used it against my current working copy (so I learned something here!)

item.title: By: Ryan Stille
item.dc:creator: Ryan Stille
item.description: @Steve, sometimes you can do an export, but sometimes you can't. In my case I was working with files that had come from a backup of a working copy. The files in the repository were NOT what I needed, I needed the files from the backup of the working copy.
item.content:encoded: @Steve, sometimes you can do an export, but sometimes you can’t. In my case I was working with files that had come from a backup of a working copy. The files in the repository were NOT what I needed, I needed the files from the backup of the working copy.

item.title: By: Rob Wilkerson
item.dc:creator: Rob Wilkerson
item.description:
@Steve
Sure, you could do that, but it seems like a lot more work than right clicking on a parent folder and selecting an option from a context menu. And what if you have changes in your working copy from what's in the repository?

item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description: Just curious - couldn't you just do an SVN Export and then replace the original folder with the exported copy? The exported copy doesn't have any of the .svn stuff in it.
item.content:encoded: Just curious – couldn’t you just do an SVN Export and then replace the original folder with the exported copy? The exported copy doesn’t have any of the .svn stuff in it.
